awd_abstract_narration:
Roadtrip Nation LTD (RTN) will produce the Computer Science (CS) Innovation Roadtrip, which will leverage RTN's multimedia content deliverables, evidence-based educational resources, and peer-to-peer student engagement strategies in order to increase the number and diversity of the nation's underrepresented high school students interested in pursuing computer science education and computing careers. At the same time, this project aims to shift perceptions among adult stakeholders, broadening their views on computing and the computing workforce. 

Founded in 2001, RTN is an award-winning media and education organization that empowers students to define their own roads in life through a public television series, live campus events, an online content database, and innovative educational resources that serve an audience of 14 million students each year. The CS Innovation Roadtrip will focus RTN's content development and programmatic capacity on highlighting the stories of diverse individuals who are driving innovation across the computing disciplines. These interviews, conducted by students, will be produced by the RTN production team for distribution across a variety of media and education networks, including RTN's documentary series on public television (presented by KQED), the Roadmap to Careers tool in collaboration with The College Board (reaching all Scholastic Aptitude Test and Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test takers), and via a partnership with the National Center for Women and Information Technology (NCWIT) Alliance network. Where appropriate, the educational materials and approaches developed as part of the CS Innovation Roadtrip will map to the Computer Science Teachers of America educational standards, Next Generation Science Standards, Common Core State Standards, and the Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles curricular framework.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Computer Science Innovation Roadtrip (CS Innovation Roadtrip) project was designed to create and disseminate multimedia content deliverables and evidence-based educational resources to increase the number and diversity of the nation?s underrepresented high school students interested in pursuing computer science education and computing careers. The project simultaneously aimed to shift perceptions among adult stakeholders to broaden views of the computing workforce.

To achieve these goals, Roadtrip Nation launched a cross-country road trip with three students underrepresented in Computer Science in the fall of 2019, interviewing thirteen diverse CS professionals working in various computing disciplines. From these interviews and the content filmed on the road, a range of multimedia resources were created and distributed in the fall of 2020, including a 1-hour documentary for Public Television, digital short-form videos, and a 4-lesson project-based curriculum entitled Code Your Road. In order to promote the use of the content, a robust outreach and communications strategy was developed in partnership with the National Center for Women and Information Technology (NCWIT) and Constellations Center for Equity in Computing. Additionally, a virtual event series was hosted during Computer Science Education Week 2020, and an educator viewing guide was created to complement the documentary, focused on ensuring that high school students from diverse backgrounds are made aware of and become engaged in learning about a variety of computing pathways.

To determine the impact of the virtual event series and the online curriculum, third party evaluator Inflexion examined the extent to which students and adults interacting with the CS Innovation Roadtrip educational resources demonstrated 1) increased student interest and excitement in computer science as a career pathway and 2) measurable impact on the attitudes and beliefs held by stakeholder adults about computer science career pathways. Surveys used to collect evaluation data remotely were developed via an iterative collaborative process between the Roadtrip Nation and Inflexion teams in the fall and winter of 2020?21. The event survey was administered in December of 2020 following the roll out of the digital series, while the educator and student surveys were administered in the spring of 2021 when the curriculum was piloted in participating schools. The Inflexion team conducted an analysis of the survey data in the summer of 2021. The following are general results by evaluation focus and respondent.

Virtual Events:

  • Educators, parents, and students attending the event(s) most strongly agreed they have a better understanding of the importance of diverse people in computer science jobs after participating, while attendees from other roles most strongly agreed they are more interested in learning about computer science.

  • The majority of event survey respondents indicated via their comments that the most helpful aspect of the event(s) they attended was increased information about/awareness of computer science, followed by appreciative comments about voices of experts and content creators as speakers during the events.

Code Your Road Curriculum:

Student Results

  • Across seven survey statements relating to student interest in computer science, pre to post survey ratings were statistically significantly different for three of the statements. After participating in the Code Your Road curriculum, students reported significantly higher agreement that there are many opportunities for them to work in the field of computer science, they are interested in pursuing a career in computer science, and they see people who are role models for them in the field of computer science.

  • Student survey respondents noted the most important things they learned while engaging with the Code Your Road curriculum fell within three main categories: increased awareness of career pathways in computer science, increased awareness of the importance of computer science in everyday life, and increased awareness of the specific skills related to computer science.

Educator Results

  • Teachers strongly agreed that after participating in Code Your Road, their students were able to better understand how their interests relate to their future career pathways. In addition, overall, teachers agreed student attitudes toward computer science were affected by the Code Your Road curriculum; specifically, teachers most strongly agreed Code Your Road helped their students learn something new about the possibilities of career paths in computer science.

  • Teacher respondents noted the positive impact of the Code Your Road curriculum on students? perceptions of computer science, centered on allowing students the time and space to learn more about the field and career pathways in computer science specifically, as well as the types of considerations when thinking about future career pathways in general.

Based on the findings of this study, the resources appear to have effectively achieved the goals of increasing interest in computer science education and computing pathways among underrepresented students, as well as broadening the views of the computing workforce anong adult stakeholders.

 


Last Modified: 09/20/2021
Modified by: Mike W Marriner
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Computer Science Innovation Roadtrip (CS Innovation Roadtrip) project was designed to create and disseminate multimedia content deliverables and evidence-based educational resources to increase the number and diversity of the nation?s underrepresented high school students interested in pursuing computer science education and computing careers. The project simultaneously aimed to shift perceptions among adult stakeholders to broaden views of the computing workforce.
To achieve these goals, Roadtrip Nation launched a cross-country road trip with three students underrepresented in Computer Science in the fall of 2019, interviewing thirteen diverse CS professionals working in various computing disciplines. From these interviews and the content filmed on the road, a range of multimedia resources were created and distributed in the fall of 2020, including a 1-hour documentary for Public Television, digital short-form videos, and a 4-lesson project-based curriculum entitled Code Your Road. In order to promote the use of the content, a robust outreach and communications strategy was developed in partnership with the National Center for Women and Information Technology (NCWIT) and Constellations Center for Equity in Computing. Additionally, a virtual event series was hosted during Computer Science Education Week 2020, and an educator viewing guide was created to complement the documentary, focused on ensuring that high school students from diverse backgrounds are made aware of and become engaged in learning about a variety of computing pathways.

The Inflexion team conducted an analysis of the survey data in the summer of 2021. The following are general results by evaluation focus and respondent.
Virtual Events:


Educators, parents, and students attending the event(s) most strongly agreed they have a better understanding of the importance of diverse people in computer science jobs after participating, while attendees from other roles most strongly agreed they are more interested in learning about computer science.


The majority of event survey respondents indicated via their comments that the most helpful aspect of the event(s) they attended was increased information about/awareness of computer science, followed by appreciative comments about voices of experts and content creators as speakers during the events.


Code Your Road Curriculum:
Student Results

After participating in the Code Your Road curriculum, students reported significantly higher agreement that there are many opportunities for them to work in the field of computer science, they are interested in pursuing a career in computer science, and they see people who are role models for them in the field of computer science.


Student survey respondents noted the most important things they learned while engaging with the Code Your Road curriculum fell within three main categories: increased awareness of career pathways in computer science, increased awareness of the importance of computer science in everyday life, and increased awareness of the specific skills related to computer science.

Teachers strongly agreed that after participating in Code Your Road, their students were able to better understand how their interests relate to their future career pathways. In addition, overall, teachers agreed student attitudes toward computer science were affected by the Code Your Road curriculum; specifically, teachers most strongly agreed Code Your Road helped their students learn something new about the possibilities of career paths in computer science.


Teacher respondents noted the positive impact of the Code Your Road curriculum on students? perceptions of computer science, centered on allowing students the time and space to learn more about the field and career pathways in computer science specifically, as well as the types of considerations when thinking about future career pathways in general.


Based on the findings of this study, the resources appear to have effectively achieved the goals of increasing interest in computer science education and computing pathways among underrepresented students, as well as broadening the views of the computing workforce anong adult stakeholders.
